I think a better way to combat the counterintuitive nature of this concept is to introduce multiple “light bulbs” in the circuit, some of which are “before” the light bulb in question (henceforth known as Light Zero or L0), and some of which are “after” that same light bulb, but all of which are in the same in-series circuit. In that case, given ideal conditions, the light from the bulb closest to the switch-flicker would reach that person first, in 1/c seconds as per this solution. Light from bulbs both “backward” and “forward” of this L0 bulb within the context of the (albeit impossibly perfect) series circuit would all appear to become lit LATER than bulb L0. This would better demonstrate that the location in the circuit is less a determining factor in the solution of this problem than the physical limit of C, resulting in bulbs “further away” than L0, though intuitively lit “earlier”, appear to brighten later than L0. It’s the proximity to the switch-flicker that defines the delay for any given Light Bulb in the circuit… thus a general answer for the time taken for a light bulb visibly brightening would be time in seconds = d/c, where d is the distance of the bulb from the operator of the switch. This is more general than 1/c, which is only correct in the original problem because d=1.

The video isn’t incorrect, it just could have made this distinction more clear… 1/c is a specific solution. d/c is the general solution.

But add gravity, and it rotates it, and that breaks the symmetry. Add not just gravity but go past the event horizon of a black hole, and it rotates it more than 45 degrees and time and space change roles. If gravity was time reversible, then if you received a photon, and in response fired a new photon in exactly the direction the photon you received came from, it would follow precisely the path it followed to get to you and land precisely where the photon you received came from. But that obviously isn't going to work if you're below the event horizon of a black hole. And it actually also doesn't work if you're outside the event horizon too, it just isn't so obvious why it fails. Frame dragging messes it up. If you are OUTSIDE of a black hole that is rotating, and you fire a photon out in exactly the same path one you received came from, it will NOT fly out and retrace the path of the other one, the sideways gravity of frame dragging will completely mess that up.

The only logical (or perhaps most fundamental) explanation to any property of reality or physics that I can deduce, always relies on entropy. The universe we know in 3D is just a single macrostate. In 4D there are just a lot of microstates (infinite ones) and together form the multiverse. In this multiverse, there are a lot of similar microstates that are indistinguishable to 'us'*, which make up a single macrostate.

This is where the concept of time comes in: Time is just a sequential order of macrostates in which the nearer the macrostate to another macrostate is, the more identical microstates it contains. The fewer identical microstates it contains, the farther away the events are separated.
This is analogous to time as you know it, because it takes more time (or/and energy) to change a lot than to change a little.

Memory is a function of the brain that is the only thing that gives us an idea of the existence of different macrostates. So when you talk about time and how you perceive is, you're only talking about the other macrostates that you know of. And to me that is why time is directional. It distinguishes the macrostates that effected your memory with the ones that didn't.

*(With 'us' I mean humanity or a single person as a subsystem in biggest system AKA the universe. This makes 'us' a macrostate consisting of multiple microstates as well. Using reflections to show parity symmetry seems to be misleading, because flipping the axes from positive to negative is a distinct transformation from reflecting about any plane. The 'flipping' is equivalent to reflecting about the xy, xz and yz planes consecutively, but this cannot be equivalent to a single reflection. In fact, a reflection is done about some arbitrary mirror/plane, but no such plane is associated with 'flipping'.

For those inclined with matrices, the 'flipping' transformation that 0:51 shows is represented by the following matrix:

                [-1   0   0]
R_flip  =  [0   -1   0]
                [0   0   -1]

However, the mirror reflection at around 3:00 is represented with:

                [1   0   0]
R_ref.  =  [0   1   0]
                [0   0   -1]

They are not the same transformation. In fact, any arbitrary reflection can be expressed in the form:

                [1-2a^2    -2ab        -2ac     ]
R_ref.  =  [-2ab        1-2b^2    -2bc    ]
                [-2ac         -2bc        1-2c^2]

where (a,b,c) is the unit vector perpendicular to the plane of reflection. R_flip cannot be expressed in this form, and so R_flip can't be a reflection.

I realise that the reflection achieves a similar effect to 'flipping' in that it transforms a right-handed (x,y,z) set of axes to a left-handed set, but I feel a better justification could be given in the video as to why a reflection was used where 'flipping' should have been. Especially if the two transformations can be intuitively confused for one another.

They tend to an equilibrium point that is close to max entropy but not quite, as a constantly changing system can only be at maximum entropy for an instant before any change to the system would, by definition, lower its entropy. "Perfect randomness" is actually not as stable as "near perfect randomness".

EDIT: This cobalt experiment is reproducible in many more was too. But if you use planar inversion then the spin should be reversed because the magnetic charge would be reversed.
